revision.text:
{{Infobox professional wrestler |name = 911 |birthname = Alfred Poling |caption = Poling with fans in 2015 |image = |names = '''911'''{{cite web |url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/a/911.html |title=911's OWOW profile |publisher=Online World of Wrestling |access-date=2009-11-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091129035833/http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/a/911.html| archivedate= 29 November 2009 |deadurl=no}}
Al The Sledgehammer
Big Al
Sledge Hammer
Tombstone{{cite web |url=http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=602 |title=911 - Wrestlers Database |accessdate=11 August 2012}} |height = {{height|ft=6|in=8}} |weight = {{convert|300|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1957|01|22}} |birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] |resides = [[West Creek, New Jersey]], [[United States]] |billed = |trainer = [[Larry Sharpe (wrestler) | Larry Sharpe]] |debut = 1990 |retired = 2006 }} '''Alfred Poling''' (born January 22, 1957) better known by the [[ring name]] '''911''', is an American retired [[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]], best known for his time with [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]] (ECW) between 1994 and 1996. ==Professional wrestling career== ===Early career=== Poling was trained as a wrestler by [[Larry Sharpe (wrestler) | Larry Sharpe]]. He debuted in 1990, wrestling on the [[independent circuit]] under the [[ring name]] "Al the Sledgehammer".{{cite web |url=http://www.1softball.com/WBS/WrestlingBookingSheet291.htm |title=The Wrestling Booking Sheet - Issue #291 |first=Steve |last=Appenrodt |date=1999-08-30 |accessdate=2013-08-30}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c7gHi_sgkAw |title=IWA Championship Wrestling - Derrick Dukes vs Al The Sledgehammer |first=Rob |last=Russen |year=1990 |accessdate=2013-08-30|publisher=[[YouTube]]}} ===Extreme Championship Wrestling (1994-1996)=== Poling achieved his greatest national exposure in [[Extreme Championship Wrestling|Eastern Championship Werstling]] (ECW) in the mid-1990s. He debuted in ECW as an unnamed "handler" to [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]] on the January 18, 1994 episode of ''[[ECW Hardcore TV|Eastern Championship Wrestling]]'' by defeating [[Chad Slivenski|Chad Austin]]. He joined [[Paul Heyman]]'s [[Dangerous Alliance]] [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#stable|stable]] with Sabu and [[Tazz|The Tazmaniac]]. His [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Gimmick|gimmick]] was as an enforcer of the "extreme" attitude; he was named '''911''' at ''The Night The Line was Crossed'' on February 5, where he defeated Chad Austin in a rematch. As part of his monstrous persona, he would frequently perform the [[chokeslam]] on others with little provocation, which made him quickly [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#over|popular]] with the crowd as a [[Face (professional wrestling)|fan favorite]].{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2004/11/24/pf-729421.html|title=SLAM! Speaks: What we miss about ECW|author=SLAM Wrestling staff|publisher=SLAM Wrestling|accessdate=February 16, 2015|date=November 25, 2004}} He received his first title shot in ECW at ''When Worlds Collide'', where he challenged [[Mikey Whipwreck]] for the [[ECW World Television Championship|ECW Television Championship]] but got disqualified after chokeslamming the [[Referee (professional wrestling)|referee]]. He would then enter a [[Feud (professional wrestling)|rivalry]] with [[Curtis Hughes|Mr. Hughes]], whom he defeated at [[Hardcore Heaven (1994)|Hardcore Heaven]]. On August 27, at the [[NWA World Title Tournament]], 911 participated in the [[ECW tournaments#NWA World Heavyweight Championship Tournament|namesake tournament]] for the vacant [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]], where he defeated [[Doink the Clown]] in the quarter-final after four chokeslams, before losing to [[2 Cold Scorpio]] in the semi-final.{{cite book|title=Hardcore History: The Extremely Unauthorized Story of ECW|author=Williams, Scott E.|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc|year=2013|chapter=5}} He closed the year by defeating [[The Pitbulls]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match|handicap match]] at [[Holiday Hell (1994)|Holiday Hell]]. Poling received the ''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]'' [[PWI Rookie of the Year|Rookie of the Year]] award due to his enormous popularity in ECW for the year 1994. Poling had two big matches in 1995, scoring wins over [[Ron Simmons]] at [[Hostile City Showdown (1995)|Hostile City Showdown]] and [[Jim Steele (wrestler)|Jim Steele]] at ''Barbed Wire, Hoodies and Chokeslams''. At the [[House Party (1996)|1996 House Party]] [[List of ECW supercards and pay-per-view events|event]], 911 teamed with [[Rey Mysterio|Rey Misterio, Jr.]] to defeat [[The Eliminators]] in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types|tag team match]], which would turn out to be his last match in ECW. He got involved in a brawl with [[Tazz|Taz]] after the match and a feud evolved between the two, but it was scrapped as Poling left the promotion by early 1996 after a falling out backstage with Paul Heyman over the former's treatment of the ring crew.{{cite book|title=Hardcore History: The Extremely Unauthorized Story of ECW|author=Williams, Scott E.|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc|year=2013|chapter=10}} ===World Championship Wrestling (1996-1997)=== Poling wrestled in [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW) in 1996 and 1997, under the names Tombstone,{{Cite episode |title= WCW Monday Nitro|series= WCW Monday Nitro|serieslink= WCW Monday Nitro|station= TNT (TV channel)|airdate= 1996-12-23}} Sledge Hammer{{Cite episode |title= WCW Saturday Night|series= WCW Saturday Night|serieslink= WCW Saturday Night|station= TBS (TV channel)|airdate= 1997-02-15}} and Big Al.{{Cite episode |title= WCW Saturday Night|series= WCW Saturday Night|serieslink= WCW Saturday Night|station= TBS (TV channel)|airdate= 1997-01-11}}{{Cite episode |title= WCW Saturday Night|series= WCW Saturday Night|serieslink= WCW Saturday Night|station= TBS (TV channel)|airdate= 1997-04-12}}{{Cite episode |title= WCW Saturday Night|series= WCW Saturday Night|serieslink= WCW Saturday Night|station= TBS (TV channel)|airdate= 1997-05-10}} Poling did not portray the Big Al who feuded with [[Tank Abbott]] in WCW in early 2000. ===Return to ECW=== In 1998, Poling returned to ECW at [[UltraClash (1998)|UltraClash]] in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, [[chokeslam]]ming [[Bill Wiles]]. Poling was then accompanied by manager Judge Jeff Jones, who proclaimed 911 to be the true giant of professional wrestling. They were then interrupted by [[Spike Dudley]] and had an [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#impromptu match|impromptu match]], which 911 lost in [[Squash (professional wrestling)|under a minute]]. ===Independent circuit=== Throughout the late 1990s, 911 appeared with the [[New Jersey]] based [[Jersey All Pro Wrestling]] promotion, winning the [[JAPW Heavyweight Championship]] on two occasions. He made an appearance at [[Pro-Pain Pro Wrestling]] ''A War Renewed'' on June 29th, 2002 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, interfering on the behalf of [[Tod Gordon]] and [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]], delivering a chokeslam to [[Sandman (wrestler)|Sandman]] (who had just been betrayed by his partner, [[Bill Alfonso]]). At ''[[Hardcore Homecoming]]'' in 2005 he chokeslammed both [[Danny Doring]] and [[Roadkill (wrestler)|Roadkill]]. He wrestled at New York Wrestling League in 2008. ==Personal life== Poling resides in [[West Creek, New Jersey]]. ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''All American Wrestling Alliance''' **AAWA Heavyweight Championship (1 time) *'''[[Jersey All Pro Wrestling]]''' **[[JAPW Heavyweight Championship]] ([[JAPW Heavyweight Championship#Title history|2 times]]) *'''New Jack City Wrestling''' **NJCW Heavyweight Championship (2 times) *'''[[List of National Wrestling Alliance territories|NWA New Jersey]]''' **[[NWA New Jersey State Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA New Jersey State Heavyweight Championship#Title history|2 times]]) **[[NWA World Light Heavyweight Championship (New Jersey version)|NWA World Light Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA World Light Heavyweight Championship (New Jersey version)#Title history|1 time]]) *'''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''' **[[PWI Rookie of the Year|Rookie of the Year]] (1994) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Professional wrestling}} *{{IMDb name|id=1407632|name=Al Poling}} {{DEFAULTSORT:911}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:American male professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Professional wrestlers from New York (state)]] [[Category:Professional wrestling managers and valets]] [[Category:Sportspeople from New York City]] [[Category:The Dangerous Alliance members]]

{{other uses|Aikanaka (disambiguation)}} In [[Hawaiian mythology]], '''ʻAikanaka''' (or '''ʻAi Kanaka''', '''ʻAikane''') is a [[Human|mortal]] chief who married [[Lona (mythology)|Lona]], the [[moon goddess]]. They lived happily together in her palace until he died of old age.<ref>''Pacific mythology: an encyclopedia of myth and legend'' by [[Jan Knappert]]</ref><ref>''Academic Dictionary Of Mythology'' by [[Ramesh Chopra]]</ref>
His name means "man eater".
ʻAikanaka also married [[hina (goddess)|Hinahanaiakamalama]] (according to the Ulu [[genealogy]]). She bore him sons [[Hemā (mythology)|Hemā]] and Puna.<ref>E.R. Tregear, Maori-Polynesian Comparative Dictionary (Lyon and Blair: Lambton Quay), 1891.</ref>
Both Lona and Hinahanaiakamalama are [[lunar deity|lunar goddesses]], so it is likely that they are the same person, and ʻAikanaka is married to just one woman.<ref>[[Martha Warren Beckwith]], pp. 214-25</ref>
According to Ulu genealogy, ʻAikanaka was born ca. 746.
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aikanaka}} [[Category:Hawaiian mythology]] [[Category:Ancient Hawaiian royalty]] [[Category:746 births]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:Legendary people]]

revision.comment: Reverted 3 edits by [[Special:Contributions/69.126.244.172|69.126.244.172]] ([[User talk:69.126.244.172|talk]]) to last revision by Wikiuser100. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox prepared food | name = Al pastor | image = alpastor 2.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = A "trompo" of pastor meat | alternate_name = | country = [[Mexico]] | region = | creator = | course = | type = | served = Warm | main_ingredient = [[Pork]] [[meat]] | variations = | calories = | other = | no_commons = }}
'''Al pastor''' (from [[Spanish language|Spanish]], "shepherd style"), also known as '''tacos al pastor''', is a dish developed in central Mexico that is based on [[shawarma]] spit-grilled [[meat]] brought by [[Lebanese immigration to Mexico|Lebanese immigrants to Mexico]].<ref>David Sterling, "The Lebanese Connection," ''Yucatan: A Culinary Expedition''. http://www.los-dos.com/culinary-expedition/verarticulo.php?IdArticulo=258</ref> Being derived from shawarma, it is also similar to the Turkish [[döner kebab]] and the Greek [[Gyro (food)|gyros]]. In contrast to döner kebab and shawarma however, tacos al pastor are pork based. In some places of northern Mexico, as in [[Baja California]], this [[taco]] is called '''taco de [[adobada]]'''. A similar dish from [[Puebla]] with different spices is '''tacos árabes'''.<ref name="Peterson 2015">{{Cite web |url=https://la.eater.com/2015/3/26/8294151/tacos-arabes-boyle-heights-taco-truck-review-photos |title=These Massive Tacos Árabes in Boyle Heights Pack a Punch |last=Peterson |first=Lucas |date=26 March 2015 |website=[[Eater.com]] LA |access-date=2018-03-10}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Dönerci, 1855.jpg|200px|thumb|right|The earliest known photo of meat cooked on a vertical rotisserie, aka [[Doner kebab|döner]], by [[James Robertson (photographer)|James Robertson]], 1855, [[Ottoman Empire]]]]
A wave of mainly Christian [[Lebanese Mexicans|Lebanese immigration to Mexico]] took place in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In the 1960s, Mexican-born progeny of Lebanese immigrants began opening their own restaurants and combining their heritage with Mexican cuisine.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pri.org/stories/2015-05-07/thank-ottoman-empire-taco-youre-eating|title=Thank the Ottoman Empire for the taco al pastor|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref>
Grilling a vertical spit of stacked meat slices and cutting it off as it cooks was developed in the 19th century in [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Turkey]].<ref name="Zeit 1996-05-10">{{cite web |url=http://www.zeit.de/1996/20/Doener-Fieber_sogar_in_Hoyerswerda |title=Döner-Fieber sogar in Hoyerswerda |author=Eberhard Seidel-Pielen |date=May 10, 1996 |website=ZEIT ONLINE |publisher= |language=German |trans-title=Doner fever even in Hoyerswerda |accessdate=May 6, 2016}}</ref><ref name="kiple">Kenneth F. Kiple, Kriemhild Coneè Ornelas, eds., ''Cambridge World History of Food'', Cambridge, 2000. {{ISBN|0-521-40216-6}}. Vol. 2, p. 1147</ref> This is [[döner kebab]], which is the origin of tacos al pastor, Middle Eastern [[shawarma]], and Greek [[gyros]].
==Preparation== [[Pork]] is marinated in a combination of dried [[Chili pepper|chilies]], [[spice]]s and [[pineapple]]. In some places, [[achiote]] is also added, and then slowly cooked with a gas flame on a vertical [[rotisserie]] called a ''trompo'' (lit: [[Top|spinning top]]), very similar to how shawarma is cooked, with a piece of fresh onion and a pineapple on top.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mexconnect.com/mex_/recipes/puebla/kgtacos2.html|title=Wrap It Up: A Guide To Mexican Street Tacos - Part 2: Nighttime Tacos : Mexico Cuisine|publisher=}}</ref> When ready, the meat is then thinly sliced off the spit with a large knife. It is served on small [[tortilla]]s, with finely chopped [[onion]]s, [[cilantro]], and occasionally a small slice of pineapple, and usually topped with some [[lemon]] or [[Lime (fruit)|lime]] juice and hot [[Salsa (sauce)|salsa]]. This meat is a common ingredient in not just [[taco]]s, but also [[gringas]], [[alambre]]s, [[Huarache (food)|huaraches]], [[torta]]s, [[burrito]]s and [[pizza]].
[[file:01 Tacos al Pastor.jpg|Plate of tacos al pastor|thumb|left]]
==Varieties== In some places of northern Mexico, such as [[Nuevo León]], [[Durango]] and [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], these are usually called ''tacos de trompo'' if served on [[corn tortilla]]s, and ''[[gringas]]'' if they are served with cheese on [[wheat tortilla]]s.
A similar dish is called ''tacos árabes'', which originated in [[Puebla]] in the 1930s from [[Arab Mexican]] cuisine. Tacos árabes use shawarma-style meat carved from a spit, but are served in a [[pita]]-style bread called ''pan árabe''. These tacos have been brought by [[Mexican Americans|Mexican immigrants to the United States]] in the past few years and have become popular in cities, such as Chicago and Los Angeles, two of the largest Mexican/Mexican-American population centers in the United States.<ref>David Hammond, "Perfection on a Spit," ''Chicago Reader'', November 8, 2007.http://www.chicagoreader.com/features/stories/restaurants/071108/</ref>
A non-pork version featuring chicken marinated in the "al pastor" style was brought "back" to the Middle East in the early 2000s, and sold as "shawarma mexici". It is essentially a chicken shawarma made in the Middle Eastern style (wrapped with garlic mayonnaise, [[dill pickle]], and [[french fries]] in a thin [[flatbread]]).
==See also== {{portal|food}} * [[Dürüm]] * [[List of Mexican dishes]] * [[Sandwich]] * [[Street food]]
==References== <references/>
{{Mexican cuisine}} {{Sandwiches}} {{Street food}}
[[Category:Mexican cuisine]] [[Category:Meat]] [[Category:Sandwiches]] [[Category:Spit-cooked foods]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Peter Karageorgevitch]] (link changed to [[Peter I of Serbia]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}}
[[File:Alice Askew in feather hat - framed.jpg|thumb|Alice Askew with feather hat, unsigned photograph, c. 1908.]]
'''Alice Askew''' (18 June 1874{{spaced ndash}}6 October 1917)<ref name=death>Death notice in ''[[The Times]]'', 15 October 1917, p. 11</ref><ref name=news>Two news clippings from the ''[[Daily Express]]'', Tuesday, 16 October 1917, and Thursday, 18 October 1917 (page numbers unknown) – the first reporting Alice Askew and her husband Claude "drowned in a torpedoed vessel in the Mediterranean on October 5"; while the second that "the Italian steamer Bari, (...) was torpedoed by a German submarine off the Ionian Islands at 4 a.m. on October 6". "These clippings are among the family artifacts now in my possession – previously in that of my aunt, Alice Askew's youngest child, G.M.A." —R.C.A.</ref><ref name=probate>Probate notice in ''[[The Times]]'', 19 October 1917, p. 4</ref> along with her husband, '''Claude Askew''' (27 November 1865{{spaced ndash}}6 October 1917)<ref name=death /><ref name=news /><ref name=probate /><ref name=hisbirth>GRO Birth certificate – registered 1 January 1866</ref> were British authors, who together wrote "over ninety novels, many published in sixpenny and sevenpenny series, between 1904 and 1918".<ref>''Edwardian Fiction – an Oxford Companion'', Oxford University Press, 1997 by Sandra Kemp, Charlotte Mitchell and David Trotter, p.10</ref><ref name=Adrian>Jack Adrian's 'Introduction' to: Alice and Claude Askew’s ''Aylmer Vance: Ghost-Seer'', edited by Jack Adrian, Ash-Tree Press, Ashcroft, British Columbia, 1998, pp. ix–xv</ref>
==Claude== [[File:Claude Askew in Serbian uniform.jpg|thumb|left|Claude Askew in Serbian uniform, unsigned photograph, c. 1916]]
Claude was born on 27 November 1865 at No. 4 Holland Park, Kensington in London and christened '''Claude Arthur Cary'''. He was the second son and youngest of five children of Fanny Georgiana Charlotte Askew (née Browne 1830–1900) and Rev. John Askew, M.A. (1804–1881).<ref name="hisbirth" /><ref>''[[The Times]]'', 2 December 1865, p. 1</ref> Claude's older sisters and brother were: Amy Ellen Cary Askew (10 June 1857 – 29 April 1945), Isabel Emily Florence Askew (16 November 1858 – 30 October 1928), Mabel Fanny Mary Askew (23 February 1861 – 21 August 1941), and Hugh Henry John Percy Cary Askew (18 September 1862 – 14 April 1949).
Claude was educated at Eton College (1879–1883), "... and there wrote a play in blank verse...." <ref name="Adrian" /> It was probably during this period — certainly after 1877 and before 1883 — when Claude was taken on a holiday to [[Vevey]] (between [[Montreux]] and [[Lausanne]]) on [[Lake Geneva]], where he met the future King [[Peter I of Serbia]] – then in exile in [[Geneva]]. "I was a small boy, spending my holidays with my people at Vevy on the Lake of Geneva, and at the hotel we struck up an acquaintance with Prince [[Peter I of Serbia|Peter Karageorgevitch]]. He was then in the prime of life, tall, dark, handsome—not yet married." He wrote this many years later recalling this childhood encounter when he met up with him once more – this time with his wife Alice and during the much darker circumstances of the 'Great Serbian Retreat' during [[World War I]] (see below). "At Koshumlja to-day we saw the King. Curiously enough, this was the first time that I have come across him since I have been in [[Serbia]], though Alice has seen him at [[Topola]]. He is a fine old man, and neither trouble, sickness, nor age has bowed him."<ref>{{cite book|pages=186–187|last1=Askew|first1=Alice|last2=Askew|first2=Claude|title=The Stricken Land: Serbia As We Saw It|date=1916|publisher=Dodd, Mead|location=New York|url=http://theworldwar.pastperfect-online.com/35156cgi/mweb.exe?request=record;id=202D36BA-466F-4FE6-98B2-983262855500;type=201}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Stricken Land: Serbia As We Saw It|url=https://archive.org/details/strickenlandserb00aske|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Alice== Alice was born on 18 June 1874 at No. 3 Westbourne Street, near Hyde Park in London, England; and christened '''Alice Jane de Courcy''' on 5 August 1874 at the church of St. Michael and All Angels in Paddington, London. She was the eldest daughter of Jane Leake (née Dashwood 1844–1912) and Henry Leake (1829–1899), who following his retirement from the British army, was granted the honorary rank of Lt-Colonel.<ref>''[[The Times]]'', 20 June 1874, p. 1</ref><ref>''[[The Times]]'', 11 January 1882, p. 8</ref> At the time of her birth he was a Captain, on half pay, late of the [[70th (Surrey) Regiment of Foot]]. She had two younger siblings: Henry Dashwood Stucley Leake (17 Feb 1876 – 2 June 1970),<ref>GRO Birth certificate – registered 25 April 1876</ref><ref>Certified Copy of an Entry of Death – General Register Office (GRO) – registered 2 June 1970</ref> and Frances Beatrice Levine Leake (27 May 1878 – 29 Aug 1884).<ref>GRO Birth certificate – registered 22 June 1874</ref><ref>GRO Death certificate – registered 30 August 1884</ref>
She began writing "for her own amusement" before her marriage, did have one short story published under her own name alone (or rather initials), "A. J. de C. L." = '''Alice Jane de Courcy Leake''': 'A Modern-Day Saint', which appeared in 1894 in ''[[Belgravia (magazine)|Belgravia]]'' of London.<ref name=Adrian /><ref>''Belgravia'': A London Magazine, Volume 85 (September to December 1894), London: F.V. White & Co., 14, Bedford Street, Strand, W.C.,1894, pp. 279–287.</ref>
==Marriage and partnership== Alice and Claude were married on 10 July 1900, at Christ Church, Lancaster Gate, London.<ref>''[[The Times]]'', 13 July 1900, p. 1</ref><ref>Certified Copy of an Entry of Marriage – General Register Office (GRO)</ref> :A PICTURESQUE WEDDING: “There was a large and fashionable congregation on Tuesday afternoon at Christ Church, Lancaster Gate, to witness the marriage of Mr. Claude Arthur Cary Askew, second son of the late Rev. John Askew, M.A., to Miss Alice Jane de Courcey Leake, only surviving daughter of the late Lieut.-Colonel Henry Leake, late 44th and 70th Regiments, and of Mrs. Leake, 3, Westbourne Street, Hyde Park. The bridegroom, who is the proprietor of the Anglo-American Exchange, of London, New York, and Paris, has a host of friends and acquaintances among American visitors now in London, many of whom were present at the ceremony. ....” <ref>Newspaper clipping with neither the name of the newspaper nor the date it was published, under the heading: A PICTURESQUE WEDDING. "This clipping is among the family artifacts now in my possession – previously in that of my aunt, Alice Askew's youngest child, G.M.A." —R.C.A.</ref>
Shortly after their marriage, Alice and Claude Askew began writing together and the first novel under their joint names, ''[[The Shulamite]],'' was published in 1904.<ref>Alice & Claude Askew, ''The Shulamite'', Chapman & Hall, London, 1904</ref> Afterwards Claude, together with [[Edward Knoblock]], wrote a stage adaptation of it, which was first produced in 1906 at the [[Savoy Theatre]], London starring [[Lena Ashwell]], and a little later with Miss Ashwell in the same role in New York City.<ref>''[[The New York Times]]'', 3 June 1906 'The Stage Abroad'</ref><ref>Wilson, A.E.: ''Edwardian Theatre'', Arthur Barker Ltd., London, 1951, pp. 119, 154</ref> In 1921 Paramount Pictures produced a silent film version with the title ''[[Under the Lash]]'' starring [[Gloria Swanson]], and directed by [[Sam Wood]].<ref>[https://uk.imdb.com/title/tt0012790/ ''Under the Lash'' at IMDb]</ref> The couple went on to publish "a large number of novels and serial stories".<ref name=death />
[[File:Alice Askew in Serbian nurse's uniform.jpg|thumb|200px|left|alt=A|Alice Askew in Serbian nurse's uniform, unsigned photograph, c. 1916.]]
In 1915, during the First World War, both Alice and Claude Askew traveled to [[Serbia]] as part of a relief effort with a British field hospital that would be attached to the Second Serbian Army. They were also Special Correspondents for the British newspaper ''[[Daily Express]]''. As Claude himself describes their role: "As for Alice and myself, we went out essentially as writers, though we were prepared to turn our hands to odd jobs if called upon to do so. We had assisted Dr. Hartnell Beavis in London with the formation of the unit, the raising of funds, and the collection of stores. It was the reports in the English Press of the terrible state into which Serbia had fallen during the winter of 1914–1915 that first inspired us to work for that gallant little country." He wrote this in their personal account of their experiences and impressions accompanying the Serbian army on its famous 'Great Retreat' across the mountains from [[Prishtina]] to [[Lezhë|Alessio]], during the winter of 1915–16, which was published in 1916 under the title: ''The Stricken Land: Serbia As We Saw It.''<ref>Askew, 1916, p. 17</ref> The authors had spent some six months in Serbia before the retreat and wrote with sympathy and real knowledge of Serbia and the Serbian character.<ref name=death /> Claude Askew was given the honorary commission of a major in the Serbian army.<ref>Askew, 1916, p. 54</ref>
Following the 'Great Serbian Retreat' (see: [[Serbian Campaign (World War I)|Serbian Campaign]]), when the bulk of the Serbian army had been evacuated to the Greek island of [[Corfu]], Alice and Claude both returned to England, which they reached by April 1916. By sometime in May, after finishing and arranging the publication of ''The Stricken Land'', Claude was back with the Serbian army – now at Salonika (as [[Thessaloniki]] was then called in English), where he was working out of its Press Bureau. But Alice remained in London to give birth to her third child, who was born towards the end of July 1916. She was also spending the time in England soliciting support for the relief work with Serbia. But in October she also returned to the theatre of war and was with her husband Claude in Salonika until about the end of April of the following year, when she went to Corfu to work with the Serbian Red Cross there, under Colonel Borissavljevitch.<ref>Letter, dated 22 March 1917, which Claude Askew wrote to his niece in London, with the return address: "Press Bureau, Headquarters, Serbian army, Salonica", in which he wrote: "Alice left this part of the world about three weeks ago. She has gone to Corfu where she is busy working for Colonel Borissavljevitch, President of the Serbian Red Cross – her address is care of him. I was anxious for her, in those days of submarines, until I heard she had safely arrived – that was by telegram – I have no letter from her yet, but it takes as long for a letter to get here from Corfu as from England. If I can get leave, which is very doubtful, I may join her later on for a month, but one cannot see into the future and all sorts of things may happen out here." "This letter is among the family artifacts now in my possession – previously in that of G.M.A." —R.C.A.</ref>
==Death== [[File:Alice askew grave.JPG|thumb|right|upright|Alice Askew's tombstone]]
Sometime between at least September and October 1917, Alice and Claude were on leave in Italy – perhaps in Rome to meet up with their two older children.<ref>Letter, dated 19 July 1917, which Alice Askew wrote to her friend, Miss Mildred Watson in London, with the return address (in French):"Care of Colonel Borissavljevitch, President Serbian Red Cross, Corfu", in which she wrote: "I am hoping to see Geoffrey & Joan, last October makes it nearly nine months since I saw the children & I am longing to have them with me for a month. I have been given a month’s leave to go to Rome in the hope of meeting them there." "This letter is among the family artifacts now in my possession – previously in that of G.M.A." —R.C.A.)</ref> Then they set out to return to Corfu. During the night of 5–6 October 1917 (or possibly the 4th) when they were traveling on the Italian steamer ''Città di Bari'' from [[Taranto]] to Corfu, it suffered a torpedo attack by the German submarine, [[SM UB-48]] "about 37 miles from Paxo" (or [[Paxoi]]) and was sunk.<ref name=news /><ref>[http://www.pietrigrandeguerra.it/voci-e-volti-dal-fronte-2/affondamenti-navi-grande-guerra-1917-1918/ Affondamenti navi Grande Guerra 1917-1918] Web site on Italian ships sunk during the First World War - this page covering the period 1917-18</ref><ref>[http://www.lavocedelmarinaio.com/2016/10/4-10-1917-il-triste-epilogo-del-piroscafo-citta-di-bari/ '4.10.1917, il triste epilogo del piroscafo Città di Bari'] Web site in Italian containing the story by Prof. Giovanni Vernì – LA VERA STORIA del triste epilogo del piroscafo “Città di Bari”, silurato dal SMG tedesco UB48 - "The True Story" of the sinking of the ''Città di Bari'' including the recollections of a survivor.</ref><ref>[http://uboat.net/wwi/ships_hit/1286.html Ships hit during WWI - Citta Di Bari] Web site on "all the German U-boats of both World Wars" - this page showing the ''Città di Bari'' as one of the ships hit during WWI.</ref> Both drowned in the incident.<ref name=death /><ref name=probate /> Claude's body was never recovered, but on 29 October the body of a woman was "found on the seashore at Porto Karboni on the island of [[Korčula]]" by a local fisherman. The next day it was examined by the authorities and, from various letters and telegrams that were found about her person, identified as that of the "well-known English lady writer Alice Askew of London."<ref>Translation of an original document sent "To the Imperial Royal District Authorities (Bezirkshauptmannschaft), Korčula (Curzola), Velaluka, 6 November 1917 ... (signed) Gracin, Sergeant". "This English translation and what appears to be the original document, hand-written (in Croatian), signed and sealed – or possibly an equally hand-written, signed and sealed copy of it – are among the family artifacts now in my possession – previously in that of G.M.A." —R.C.A.</ref> Alice Askew was then buried that same day 30 October 1917 at Porto Karboni. And a stone cross was erected there, bearing the following inscription: ALICE ASKEW / {{smallcaps|englezka spisateljica / donesena morem 29 / a pokopana / komissionalno / 30 oktobra 1917}} - (roughly translated from the original Croatian: "ALICE ASKEW / English writer / delivered up from the sea 29 / and buried / by commission / 30 October 1917").<ref>Fazinić, Neven ing., Korčula, Croatia: ''Kameni Križevi Na Otoku Korčuli'' (Stone crosses on the island of Korčula) – article with photographs, dated 06.10.2006, that was originally accessed on [http://www.ikorcula.net/korcula_info/prikazi/kameni-krizevi-na-otoku-korculi.htm ikorcula.net]</ref>
Previously – on 21 October 1917, a memorial service for Alice and Claude Askew was held at the Serbian Church in Corfu, attended by a large number of both Serbian and British officials. It was conducted by the Archbishop of Serbia, "who paid an eloquent and touching tribute to the benevolent work of Major and Mrs. Askew, to whom, he said, the Serbian people owed eternal gratitude".<ref>"Imperial and Foreign News Items" in ''[[The Times]]'', 23 October 1917, p. 7.</ref>
Alice and Claude Askew were survived by one son and two daughters.
==Selected works==
*''The Shulamite'' (1904) *''The Plains of Silence'' (1907) *''Lucy Gort: A Study in Temperament'' (1907) *''The Rod of Justice'' (1910) *''Two Apaches of Paris'' (1911) *''The Stricken Land: Serbia As We Saw It'' (1916) * ''Not Proven'' * ''The Stolen Lady'' * ''The Etonian'' * ''The Sporting Chance''

{{Spanish name 2|de Marco|Soto}} {{Infobox boxer | name = Antonio DeMarco | image = | realname = Antonio de Marco Soto | nickname = | weight = {{plainlist| *[[Lightweight]] *[[Light welterweight]] }} | height = 5 ft 10 in | reach = 71 in | nationality = Mexican | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|1|7}} | birth_place = [[Los Mochis]], [[Sinaloa]], Mexico | style = [[Southpaw stance|Southpaw]] | total = 41 | wins = 33 | KO = 24 | losses = 7 | draws = 1 | no contests = }} '''Antonio de Marco Soto''' (born January 7, 1986), best known as '''Antonio''' "'''Tony'''" '''DeMarco''', is a Mexican [[professional boxer]] who held the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] [[lightweight]] title from 2011 to 2012. He is a cousin of former two-weight world champion [[Humberto Soto]].Wainwright, Anson (2011). [http://www.maxboxing.com/news/max-boxing-news/antonio-demarco-anyone-who-is-willing-to-fight-me-i-will-accept "Antonio DeMarco: "Anyone who is willing to fight me, I will accept.""]. Max Boxing. Retrieved September 26, 2016. ==Professional career== ===Lightweight=== DeMarco claimed an interim belt after he dominated [[Jose Alfaro]] for 10 rounds before a stoppage was called. Demarco won every round before dropping Alfaro three times in the 10th round. Demarco's unbeaten streak is 15-0-1 with 10 knockouts, including 12 consecutive wins, since losing a six-round, majority decision to Anthony Vasquez in February 2006. He lined himself up to face the monster-punching full WBC titlist, [[Edwin Valero]].Christ, Scott. (2011-08-31) [http://www.badlefthook.com/2009/10/31/1109416/antonio-demarco-dominates-jose Antonio DeMarco dominates Jose Alfaro, stops him in 10]. Bad Left Hook. Retrieved on 2009-08-05. DeMarco's first chance at being world champion was unsuccessful after he was stopped by the late [[Edwin Valero]] of [[Venezuela]] to retain his WBC Lightweight belt. After absorbing 9 rounds of punishment, DeMarco's trainer advised the referee to stop the fight. DeMarco later stated, “I'm a Mexican fighter, I never wanted to quit but my trainer saw that Edwin was just a better fighter.” When the fight ended, Valero was eight points up on the scorecards of all three judges.http://ringtv.craveonline.com/blog/122905-valero-stops-demarco-looks-to-bigger-and-better-challenges-Rafael, Dan. (2010-02-07) [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=4894419 BValero stops DeMarco in ninth round]. ESPN. Retrieved on 2011-08-05. DeMarco rebounded with a second-round TKO victory over Daniel Attah. In his following fight, he defeated Reyes Sanchez by unanimous decision to win the WBC Silver Lightweight title. ===WBC lightweight champion=== On October 15, 2011, DeMarco stopped former two division champion [[Jorge Linares]] in the 11th round to claim the vacant [[List of lightweight boxing champions#WBC|WBC Lightweight title]]. On September 8, 2012, Demarco stepped into the ring to make his second world title defense against John Molina, Jr. In round 1 DeMarco landed his straight left hand onto Molina's face and sent Molina back. As DeMarco had Molina hurt and up against the ropes, the referee jumped in and called a stop to the bout, only 44 seconds into the fight. ===Light welterweight=== ====DeMarco vs. Vargas==== On November 22, 2014, Antonio DeMarco attempted to win his third world title in the junior welterweight division. DeMarco faced former olympian and current (Regular) [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] Junior Welterweight Champion [[Jesse Vargas]]. This fight took place at [[The Venetian Macao]] in [[Macau]], [[Special Administrative Regions|SAR]] on the undercard of [[Manny Pacquiao vs. Chris Algieri]] on HBO PPV. ==Professional boxing record== {{Use British English|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Archie Annan | image = | fullname = Walter Archibald Annan<ref name="Special pact">{{cite news|title=Special pact led to FA Cup Final for Bristol City legend|url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Annan-s-pact-led-City-s-FA-Cup-final-bow/story-11264350-detail/story.html|accessdate=13 June 2012|newspaper=This is Bristol|date=23 April 2009}}</ref> | position = [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Full back]] | birth_date = 23 March 1877<ref name="birth">{{cite web|title=1877 ANNAN, WALTER ARCHIBAL (Statutory registers Births 632/ 92)|url=https://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk/view-image/nrs_stat_births/41438121|website=scotlandspeople.gov.uk|publisher=National Records of Scotland|accessdate=7 August 2017|subscription=yes}}</ref> | birth_place = Wilsontown, [[Carnwath]], [[Lanarkshire]]<ref name="census">Walter Archibald Annan in the 1911 England Census; Occupation: Professional footballer</ref> | death_date = {{death year and age|1949|1875}} | death_place = [[Gloucester]], England<ref name="Special pact"/> | height = {{height|ft=5|in=10}}<ref name="Special pact"/> | years1 = 1899–1900 | clubs1 = [[West Calder F.C.|West Calder]] | caps1 = | goals1 = | years2 = 1900–1902 | clubs2 = [[St Bernard's F.C.|St Bernard's]] | caps2 = | goals2 = | years3 = 1902–1904 | clubs3 = [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] | caps3 = 1 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 1904–1905 | clubs4 = [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] | caps4 = 27 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 1904–1911 | clubs5 = [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] | caps5 = 143 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 1911–1912 | clubs6 = [[Port Vale F.C.|Burslem Port Vale]] | caps6 = 7| goals6 = 0 | manageryears1 = 1912–19?? | managerclubs1 = [[Mid Rhondda F.C.|Mid Rhondda]] }}
'''Walter Archibald Annan''' (23 March 1877 – 1949) was a Scottish professional [[association football|footballer]] in the years prior to [[World War I]]. A [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|full back]], he made over 170 appearances in [[the Football League]].<ref name="Joyce">{{cite book | first=Michael|last=Joyce | title=Football League Players' Records 1888 – 1939| publisher=Tony Brown | year=2004| isbn=1-899468-67-6}}</ref> He featured prominently in [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]]'s successes in the first decade of the 20th century under manager [[Harry Thickett]]. He also played for [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], and [[Port Vale F.C.|Burslem Port Vale]]. He helped Bristol City to the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] title in 1905–06, a second-place finish in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] in 1906–07, and also played in the [[FA Cup]] final in [[1909 FA Cup Final|1909]].
==Career== Born in [[Carnwath]], [[Lanarkshire]],<ref name="census"/> he was the youngest of 13 children<ref name="Special pact"/> born to Walter Annan, a colliery manager, and his wife Marion (''née'' Storry).<ref name="birth"/><ref>1881 Scotland Census</ref> A lifelong [[Teetotalism|teetotal]]ler,<ref name="Special pact"/> Annan joined local club West Calder in August 1899, before moving onto Edinburgh club [[St Bernard's F.C.|St Bernard's]] in May 1900. No Scottish league appearances are recorded for either club.<ref name="DykesLamming">{{cite book|first=Garth|last=Dykes|first2=Doug |last2=Lamming|title=All the Lads Complete Who's Who of Sunderland AFC|publisher=Polar|year=1999|isbn=1-899538-14-3}}</ref> In April 1902 he moved to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] of [[the Football League]]. He made a solitary appearance at right back in 2–1 win over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] on 4 April 1903, in a season when Sunderland finished third, only a single point behind champions [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].<ref name="DykesLamming" /> In January 1904 he moved on to [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], and made his league debut for the "Blades" at left back in a 2–0 defeat at [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 9 January 1904. He made a total of nine appearances at full back, deputising for [[Harry Thickett]] and Boyle in [[1903–04 Football League|1903–04]]. Annan made 18 appearances in [[1904–05 Football League|1904–05]], as United finished sixth in the First Division.
Annan followed manager Harry Thickett to [[Ashton Gate Stadium|Ashton Gate]] for £200 in April 1905.<ref name="WoodsEdwards">{{cite book|first=David|last=Woods|first2=Leigh |last2=Edwards |title=Bristol City FC The First 100 years|publisher=Redcliffe Press |year=1997|isbn=1-900178-26-5}}</ref> When [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] finished as [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] champions in [[1905–06 Football League|1905–06]], Annan was ever-present with 38 appearances at right-back, and formed a notable defensive full back partnership with [[Joe Cottle]]. Ever present again for a second successive season in [[1906–07 Football League|1906–07]], City finished the campaign as runners-up in the First Division. Annan played just 13 games in [[1907–08 Football League|1907–08]] as new signing [[Bob Young (footballer, born 1886)|Bob Young]] was preferred at right-back. In [[1908–09 Football League|1908–09]], Annan replaced Young as the regular right-back, making 26 appearances and playing in all 10 [[FA Cup]] ties, including the [[1909 FA Cup Final]] – City lost the final 1–0 to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]]. He made a further 28 appearances in [[1909–10 Football League|1909–10]], and was again replaced by Bob Young in the later stages of the season. Annan did not feature in the City team in the [[1910–11 Football League|1910–11]] season, as Bristol City were relegated back to the Second Division.<ref name="Woods">{{cite book|first=David|last=Woods|title=Bristol Babe The First 100 years of Bristol City FC|publisher=Yore Publications |year=1994|isbn=1-874427-95-X}}</ref> The final league match of the season, a 1–0 defeat to Everton on 29 April 1911, was awarded as a joint benefit for [[Arthur Spear]] and Archie Annan, although neither played in the game.<ref name="WoodsEdwards"/>
In July 1911, Annan moved onto [[Port Vale F.C.|Burslem Port Vale]].<ref name="kent">{{cite book|last=Kent|first=Jeff|title=Port Vale Personalities|publisher=Witan Books|page=7|year=1996|isbn=0-9529152-0-0|id= {{ASIN|0952915200|country=ca}}}}</ref> He made his debut at the [[Athletic Ground (Cobridge)|Athletic Ground]] in a 1–0 win over [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic Reserves]] on 4 September, but injured himself in a match against [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] twelve days later.<ref name="kent"/> He failed to hold onto his first team place upon his recovery, and was released at the end of the [[1911–12 in English football|1911–12]] season, after picking up a Central League runners-up medal.<ref name="kent"/>
Annan was appointed manager of Welsh [[Southern Football League]] club [[Mid Rhondda F.C.|Mid Rhondda]] in July 1911, where he was assisted by former Bristol City colleagues Joe Cottle and [[Bill Demmery]]. He subsequently returned to Bristol City in March 1921 and spent five years as coach at the club. He was later a police constable stationed at St George in [[Bristol]].<ref name="WoodsEdwards"/>
==Statistics== Source:<ref>{{ENFA}}</ref>
