page.title: Bahá'í Faith on life after death

revision.text:
{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The [[Bahá'í Faith]] affirms the prospect of '''life after death''' extensively while not defining everything about it. The [[soul]] on death is said to recognize the value of its deeds and begin a new phase of a conscious relationship with God though negative experiences are possible. Others have noted the religion's stances on the [[afterlife]]. == Death, dying, the soul and the afterlife == ===Teachings and beliefs=== The [[soul]] is not considered to be subject to natural law - rather it is subject to spiritual law as a covenant between man and God and it takes identity at the conception of the embryo, but not "in" the body, rather, associated with it like light to a mirror.{{Cite book|author= Taherzadeh, Adib |authorlink= Adib Taherzadeh |year= 1976 |title= The Revelation of Bahá'u'lláh, Volume 1 |publisher= George Ronald |location=Oxford, UK|isbn= 0-85398-270-8| url =http://www.peyman.info/cl/Bahá'í/Others/ROB/V1/p071-083Ch06.html#p72 |pages = 72–74}} [[Heaven]] is a soul being close to God, not a place but a condition, as it undergoes an eternal spiritual evolution.{{cite book | last = Hatcher | first = John S.|title =How Different Religions View Death and Afterlife | editor-last = Johnson | editor-first =Christopher J. |editor2-last = McGee |editor2-first =Marsha G.|publisher =The Charles Press | edition =2nd| origyear = 1986 | year = 2009|pages = 14–30, also Q&A pp. 266–300 |chapter = Bahá'í Faith (2nd chapter) | chapterurl = | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=pvHgQAAACAAJ | isbn = 9780914783855}} Anyone who learns and applies virtues and guidance of God "goes to" heaven. [[Hell]] is similarly being far from God, not a place, but of failing to understand and apply virtues and guidance from God. Progress from even the worst condition is possible even in the next world but not until the individual fundamentally overcomes rejecting Godly virtues. Labels we call ourselves by and theologies we claim to adhere to are not as important as the reality of spiritual virtues like courage, justice, love, understanding, etc., actually expressed by choice in our lives.{{cite book | title =The Handbook of Near-Death Experiences: Thirty Years of Investigation | editor-last = Holden | editor-first =Janice Miner |editor2-last = Greyson |editor2-first =Bruce| editor3-last = James |editor3-first = Debbie| publisher =Greenwood Publishing Group | date =Jun 22, 2009 | pages = 159–183 | chapter =World Religions and Near-Death Experiences | chapterurl =| last = Masumian | first = Farnaz | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=9MdUPgAACAAJ | isbn = 978-0-313-35864-7}} Development of the spiritual life reaches a milestone whether in this life or the next in developing the "spirit of faith" a gift of the Holy Spirit, which then continues to grow in the individual's soul. But if our ability to express Godly virtues is conditional so is our condition in the afterlife - there is a spectrum of achievement so a purgatory-like environment is possible for those who have not well embraced Godly virtues and those that have not largely rejected them. Indeed, the next world's life is sometimes delineated in stages.{{cite web | last =Stockman| first = Robert | title =Heaven | work =Draft of The Bahá'í Encyclopedia| publisher =Bahai-Library.com | url =http://bahai-library.com/stockman_heaven| accessdate = 2013-01-17}}{{cite journal| last =Momen| first = Moojan | title ='Abdu'l-Bahá's Commentary on the Qur'ánic Verses Concerning the Overthrow of the Byzantines: The Stages of the Soul | journal = Lights of Irfan; Papers Presented at the ‘Irfán Colloquia and Seminars | volume =2 | issue = | pages =99–118 | year =2001| url =http://irfancolloquia.org/28/momen_byzantines| accessdate = 2013-01-17}} Bahá'ís believe a significant purpose of revelation is to guide the spiritual development of the individual and that accepting the prophet of God is important as a significant chance at advancing the conditional achievement of discovering the virtues themselves and expressing them. If one succeeds in achieving these to a superlative degree then that person will be of benefit to all mankind from the afterlife while those who are far from God have no power to affect the living any more.{{cite journal | last =Hatcher| first =William S. | title =The Concept of Spirituality | journal =Bahá'í Studies | volume =11 | issue = | pages = | publisher =Ottawa: Association for Bahá'í Studies | year = 1982 | url =http://bahai-library.com/hatcher_bw18_spirituality| accessdate = 2013-01-17}}{{cite encyclopedia|last= Smith|first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith|title= burial, "death and afterlife", evil, evil spirits, sin |year= 2000|publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1|pages= 96–97, 118–119, 135–136, 322–323 }} Indeed, evil is not viewed as a power in the next world - people who are evil are described as "atrophied" and "enfeebled"{{cite book |author=`Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink=`Abdu'l-Bahá |origyear=1912 |year=1995 |title=Paris Talks|edition=Hardcover |publisher=Bahá'í Distribution Service |isbn=1-870989-57-0|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/PT/pt-31.html.utf8#gr7| pages = 96–99 }} and that accounts of "possession" are about people who have yielded to their own darker passions and baser nature. Even though heaven is a condition more than a place it is still described as a realm where those who are close to God also are close to each other.{{cite web| last =Sharon | first = Moshe | authorlink =Moshe Sharon | title =Death and Dying in the Bahá’í Faith| work =Chair in Bahá'í Studies Publications | publisher =The Hebrew University of Jerusalem | date =Jan 13, 2011 | url =https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:pu2yj-NUMtYJ:www.hum.huji.ac.il/upload/_FILE_1294940501.doc+&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESh9IEX1RyP2gRTTKBUs67cOjtFw66_boJIIYFGkqsQqDVmR4Qa9xLFpUyzEGjKZLDktFJXqiruWIVI8VOwbHDUlrWOpdDwUcXUkN9jmVgUpbh7pBaxVvn0fJkR35Jqf6C-_CD1Q&sig=AHIEtbSPu9gw2kkIAZs1216rli6YegzJeg|format = Word doc | accessdate = 2013-01-01 }} Thus in the afterlife one encounters the prophets of old and other historical people. While the individual experiences dramatic changes from birth and the stages of life in this world then death and life beyond, Bahá'ís hold it is the same soul, the same sense of identity, through the dramatic changes of circumstances. However the worlds of the womb, life in this world and the life beyond are actually interwoven. It's not like moving to a distant place - the afterlife is also "here", unseen by those living on earth. Life in this world affects that one and life in that one affects this. Death is about the letting go of the physical frame and its requirements and has no real identity itself. [[Judgement Day]] is perceived to be about the time after a new Revelator when the followers of the former dispensation are judged/tested. If they are affirmed they are "raised" or "return" (not as individuals but as types of people, like John the Baptist was the return of Elijah but not Elijah himself.){{cite book| last = Buck | first = Christopher | title =Paradise and paradigm: key symbols in Persian Christianity and the Baha’i Faith | publisher =State University of New York Press, Albany | year =2009 | pages =90–1, 189 | url =http://bahai-library.com/pdf/b/buck_paradise_paradigm.pdf | isbn =0-7914-4061-3 }} The circumstances of mass "[[resurrection]]" in the last days refers to when the process will be world embracing rather than in one country or people or another. This is also one of many reasons why Bahá'ís do not believe in the literal return to earth of the same individual soul as is believed by those who hold to reincarnation.{{cite journal | last =Bayat | first = Sateh |author2=Vafa Bayat | title =A Bahá'í Understanding of Reincarnation in Relation to the World's Faiths | journal =Lights of Irfan; Papers Presented at the ‘Irfán Colloquia and Seminars | volume =6 | issue = | pages = 21–46 | year =2004 | url =http://irfancolloquia.org/53/bayat_reincarnation | accessdate = 2013-01-17}} Thus this Judgement Day is not the same as the judgement that happens after death but there too there is a judgement and the reality behind the words one lived by are measured. Rewards for correctly applying virtues and punishments for incorrectly doing so are settled but ongoing learning still takes place starting in the last moments of earthly life. Bahá'ís believe we will know and converse with those we have known as well as those who have already died. Expressing information about the afterlife is inherently limited in this life. It is explained that the next life is fundamentally different in many ways from this life. The parallel is made comparing life in the womb with this life and the changes after birth to the changes after death. Realities of the latter are not available even as concepts in the former - they are ineffable. The idea of a body in the next world is still present but it is a heavenly body. There is a realm of lights and reunion with deceased associates. God will be witnessed as if it were a sun in the sky but there is no night. The sanctity of human nature is affirmed when it reflects the light of God and the truths of existence become known and a basic fear of death is overcome and a universal acceptance of the religions as coming from one source. ===Laws and rules=== Among the specific rules Bahá'ís are to try to follow concerning death are, depending on the civil law of their country: * No [[cremation]] or [[embalming]]. It is not a harm to the soul itself but the body is to be respected, not destroyed or harmed in general. Donation to science is allowed if the other rules can be followed. * [[Suicide]] is seen as a rejection of God's plan for humans and is forbidden to followers of the religion. The religion teaches that the souls of adherents can "suffer spiritually" if they commit suicide, but recommends that bereaving families be comforted.{{cite web | title =Suicide and the Bahá'í Faith | work =Essays and short articles | publisher =Baha'i Library.com | date =2003 | url =http://bahai-library.com/suicide_bahai_faith | accessdate = Jan 8, 2014 }} * There are no mourning rituals specified but there is a shared prayer for the dead to be read for Bahá'ís. * There is a ring with an inscription Bahá'ís should wear when buried and the body wrapped in a shroud. The inscription should read (in whatever translation of language) “I came forth from God and return unto Him, detached from all save Him, holding fast to His Name, the Merciful, the Compassionate.” * Interment of the body should be in a coffin. * Burial should take place no more than an hour's travel from the place of death. * The appropriate marker on the gravestone is a nine-pointed star and or the word Bahá'í. Other inscriptions are allowed but not required. * Bahá'í-run funerals for non-Bahá'ís require none of these requirements. * Infants who die are under the mercy and bounty of God. Mourning, the distress and pain of the loss of contact with friends and kin for Bahá'ís is, aside from cultural issues and norms in society, characterized as another stage of life - a temporary condition that will be changed someday just as someday the infant in the womb comes into the material world through birth and into the company of family and friends. Not avoiding the sense of loss, Baha'u'llah emphasizes the sense of mystery in death, pointing out that though he has shared some aspects of death and afterlife:
"“The Mysteries of man’s physical death and of his return have not been divulged, and still remain unread… Were they to be revealed, they would evoke such fear and sorrow that some would perish, while others would be so filled with gladness as to wish for death, and beseech, with unceasing longing, the one true God – exalted be His Glory – to hasten their end.”
As this is not apparent to anyone, instead we struggle with the fact of death. Bahá'ís do allow for cultural norms of societies they live in. For example, among the indigenous of [[Bahá'í Faith in Papua New Guinea|Papua New Guinea]] Christian missionaries had openly opposed traditional funerary art and performances while the Bahá'ís encouraged their production as a form of worship. Thus while [[Nalik culture|Nalik]] Bahá'ís are regarded by other Naliks as arbiters of traditional knowledge and practices, the Christian missions and their followers are seen as antagonistic to [[kastom]].{{cite journal | last =Were |first = Graeme | title =Thinking through images:''Katom'' and the coming of the Bahá'ís to Northern New Ireland, Papua New Guinea | journal =Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute |volume =11 | issue = | pages =659–676 |year =2005 | url =http://www.nhbahais.com/BahaiPapers/newguinea.pdf | accessdate = 2013-01-01 | doi=10.1111/j.1467-9655.2005.00256.x}} Bahá'ís view prayers in this world as of use to those who have passed on as are indeed their prayers for us still living in this world.{{cite book| last =Esselmont |first =John Ebenezer | authorlink =John Esslemont | editor-last =Right Rev. W.P. Paterson | editor2-last =Russell |editor2-first = David| title=The Power of Prayer| chapter =A study of Bahai prayer | chapterurl =https://books.google.com/books?id=FqUPAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA351#v=onepage| publisher =The Macmillan Company| series =being a selection of Walker trust essays, with a study of the essays as a religious and theological document | date = August 1920| pages = 351–364| url =http://openlibrary.org/books/OL6627634M/The_power_of_prayer}} Additionally remembering the lives of those who died, their achievements of virtues, and services carried out in their name is actually of assistance to those who have died. === Impressions of a Bahá'í point of view on death and the afterlife === [[A Practical Reference to Religious Diversity for Operational Police and Emergency Services]] is designed to offer guidance to police and emergency services personnel on how religious affiliation can affect their contact with the public. The second edition published in 2002 in Australia mentioned norms that could be expected of Bahá'ís in the case of dying or death.{{Cite book|title=A Practical Reference to Religious Diversity for Operational Police|publisher=Australasian Police Multicultural Advisory Bureau|edition=2nd|year=2002|pages=|url=http://www.apmab.gov.au/guide/religious2/religious_guide.pdf|isbn=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050619070219/http://www.apmab.gov.au/guide/religious2/religious_guide.pdf|archivedate=19 June 2005|page =18}} It states that Bahá'ís believe in life after death, holding that the [[soul]] is created at the moment of conception and will retain its individuality in an eternal realm. The body, which is compared to the lamp holding the light of the soul during its time in this world, should be treated with dignity. Embalming is not to take place unless required by law. The body should be transported as little as possible after death, and interment must take place within an hour's travel time from the city or town where death occurs. Cremation is forbidden. From its scriptures it is said that "the soul is a sign of God, a heavenly gem whose reality the most learned of men hath failed to grasp, and whose mystery no mind, however acute, can ever hope to unravel."{{Cite book|author=Bahá'u'lláh |authorlink=Bahá'u'lláh |year=1976 |title=Gleanings from the Writings of Bahá'u'lláh |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-87743-187-6|pages=158–163|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/GWB/gwb-82.html#gr1}} These points are noted in other sources as well.*{{cite journal| last = Siriwardena | first =A. Niroshan |author2=David H. Clark | title =End-of-Life Care for Ethnic Minority Groups | journal =Clinical Cornerstone | volume =6 | issue =1 | pages =43–49 | year =2004 | doi=10.1016/s1098-3597(04)90006-3}} * {{cite journal| last =Busse | first =Ewald W. | title =Book Review of ''How Different Religions View Death and Afterlife'', ed. by Johnson and McGee | journal =The American Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry | volume =3 | issue =2 | pages =179–180 | date =Spring 1995 | url =http://www.ajgponline.org/article/S1064-7481(12)61089-6/fulltext | doi =10.1097/00019442-199500320-00011 | accessdate =2013-01-08 }} Sociologist researchers have observed that Bahá'ís have an inclusivistic belief that although it may take work, most people will eventually be ''saved'' or get to heaven.{{cite journal | last = Johnson | first =Christopher J. |author2=Marsha McGee | title =Psychological aspects of death and dying | journal =The Gerontologist | volume =44 | issue =5 | pages =719–722 | year =2004 |doi =10.1093/geront/44.5.719 }} Television coverage of the prayer vigil on CNNsee ''Updated at 8:25 p.m. ET'' {{cite web| title = 'These tragedies must end, and to end them we must change' | work = This just in… | publisher =CNN | date =December 16, 2012 | url =http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2012/12/16/latest-updates-connecticut-school-shooting/comment-page-29/ | accessdate = 2013-01-05}} and C-Span for the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]] included Bahá'í scripture to console the living so that their affect of the recently dead was less disruptive.about from time sequence 1:07:52 to 1:10:46 {{cite video| people = John Woodall and unidentified woman | title =President Obama at Newtown, Connecticut Prayer Vigil | medium =video | publisher =C-Span Video | location =Newtown Connecticut High School | date =Dec 16, 2012 | url = http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/Newtow}} The text used at the service was adapted to apply to parents and children and taken from [[Bahá'í literature#`Abdu'-Bahá|Selections From the Writings of ‘Abdu’l-Bahá]]:
:    …the loss of a son is indeed heart-breaking and beyond the limits of human endurance, yet one who knoweth and understandeth is assured that the son hath not been lost but, rather, hath stepped from this world into another, and she will find him in the divine realm. That reunion shall be for eternity, while in this world separation is inevitable and bringeth with it a burning grief. :    Praise be unto God that thou hast faith, art turning thy face toward the everlasting Kingdom and believest in the existence of a heavenly world. Therefore be thou not disconsolate, do not languish, do not sigh, neither wail nor weep; for agitation and mourning deeply affect his soul in the divine realm. :    That beloved child addresseth thee from the hidden world: ‘O thou kind Mother, thank divine Providence that I have been freed from a small and gloomy cage and, like the birds of the meadows, have soared to the divine world—a world which is spacious, illumined, and ever gay and jubilant. Therefore, lament not, O Mother, and be not grieved; I am not of the lost, nor have I been obliterated and destroyed. I have shaken off the mortal form and have raised my banner in this spiritual world. Following this separation is everlasting companionship. Thou shalt find me in the heaven of the Lord, immersed in an ocean of light.’{{Cite book |last=`Abdu'l-Bahá |author-link = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year=1978 |editor-last = Gail |title=Selections From the Writings of `Abdu'l-Bahá |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |place=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-85398-084-5 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/SAB/sab-172.html | page =201}}
=== Bahá'í literature === The related topics of death, dying, the soul and the [[afterlife]] are of interest in the religion - covered at length in the lifetimes of the central figures of the religion through questions asked by enquirers, and then these scriptures repeatedly compiled in books.{{cite web | last = MacEoin |first = Denis |author2=William Collins | title =The Babi and Bahá'í Religions: An Annotated Bibliography {{ndash}} Compilations (Listings) |publisher= Greenwood Press's ongoing series of Bibliographies and Indexes in Religious Studies| year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/maceoin_annotated_bibliography | accessdate = 2013-01-01 |at = Entries #66, 88, 127, 144, 184, 189, 199, 209, 213, 214}} The ''Divine Art of Living'' is one such early work that has a chapter, The Realm of Immortality, which has section headings of: The Nature of the Soul, Punishments and Rewards, The Release of the Spirit, Life in the Next World, Consolation for the Bereaved, Prayers for the Departed.{{cite book| editor-last = Paine | editor-first =Mabel Hyde | title =The Divine Art of Living: Selections from the Writings of Baha'u'llah, The Bab, and Abdu'l-Baha| chapter =The Realm of Immortality | chapterurl =https://books.google.com/books?id=_GUCYPh4J8oC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA35#v=onepage |publisher =Bahá'í Publishing Trust | year =2006 | origyear = 1944 | pages = 35–44 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=_GUCYPh4J8oC | isbn = 9781931847186}} The early content originally appeared in successive issues of [[Bahá'í literature#Periodicals|World Order magazine]] from April 1940 to September 1941 and was then reprinted and revised in a single volume in 1944, 1946, 1949, 1953, 1956, 1960, 1965, 1970, 1972, 1973, 1974, 1979, 1986, 2006.{{cite book | last =Bahá'u'lláh |author2=Abdu'l-Bahá, Shoghi Effendi | editor-last = Paine | editor-first =Mabel Hyde| title =The Divine Art of Living: Selections from the Writings of Baha'u'llah, The Bab, and Abdu'l-Baha | publisher =Bahá'í Publishing Trust | year =2006 | origyear =1944 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=_GUCYPh4J8oC&lpg=PP1&pg=PR4#v=onepage |isbn = 9781931847186 }} Bahá'ís have held conferences of the same name.{{cite web| title =Divine Art of Living Conference| publisher =| url =https://dalconference.com| accessdate =2013-01-01| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130831125250/https://dalconference.com/| archive-date =2013-08-31| dead-url =yes| df =}} The massive compilation ''Lights of Guidance: A Bahá'í Reference File'' published in 1983{{cite book| last =Bahá'u'lláh | author2 =Abdu'l-Bahá |author3=Shoghi Effendi |author4=Universal House of Justice |editor-last =Hornby| editor-first = Helen| title =Lights of Guidance: A Bahá'í Reference File| chapter =Death | chapterurl =http://bahai-library.com/hornby_lights_guidance#qqqXIII | publisher =New Delhi: Bahá'í Publishing Trust | year =1983 | url =http://bahai-library.com/hornby_lights_guidance }} had sections covering scriptural compilations on the topics. Approximately 10 books were published directly on the topic of life after death. In America the manual for [[Spiritual Assembly|Bahá'í Local Assemblies]], ''Developing Distinctive Bahá'í Communities'', chapter 19, covers specifics burial practices and related topics{{cite book | title =Developing Distinctive Bahá'í COmmunities; Guidelines for Spiritual Assemblies | publisher =National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | edition = Updated 2008 | year =2008 |origyear = 1989| chapter =Chapter 19 - Bahá'í Burial | chapterurl =|pages = 20| url = }} and volume 1 of the ''Compilations of Compilations'' has an entry similarly titled.{{cite book| last =compiled by Research Department of the Universal House of Justice | title =Compilation of Compilations Volume 1 | publisher =Mona Vale: Bahá'í Publications Australia | series =Compilation of Compilations| chapter =Bahá'í Burial | chapterurl =http://bahai-library.com/compilation_bahai_burial | volume =1 | year = 1991 | pages =9–13 | url =http://bahai-library.com/compilation_compilations_1 | isbn = 9780909991548 }} These topics were continued more recently in the [[Ruhi Institute]] project in its first workbook [[Ruhi Institute#Book 1: Reflections on the Life of the Spirit|Reflections on the Life of the Spirit]] under the section "Life and Death", as well as many articles, sections or chapters in books, and whole books both scholarly and institutional.* {{cite web | last =Momen | first =Moojan | title =Afterlife and Salvation | work = | publisher =patheos.com | url =http://www.patheos.com/Library/Bahai/Beliefs/Afterlife-and-Salvation.html | accessdate =2013-01-01 }} * {{cite web | title =Heaven and hell: a Bahá'í view of life after death | work = | publisher =Bahá'í International Community | url =http://info.bahai.org/article-1-4-5-2.html | accessdate =2013-01-01 }} * {{cite web | title =Heaven and Hell: A Bahá'í Perspective | work = | publisher =National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | url =http://www.bahai.us/heaven-and-hell/ | accessdate =2013-01-01 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130302101516/http://www.bahai.us/heaven-and-hell/ | archive-date =2013-03-02 | dead-url =yes | df = }} * {{cite book | last =Bahá'u'lláh | author2 =Báb, Abdu'l-Bahá | editor-last =Motlagh | editor-first =Hushidar | title =Unto Him Shall We Return: Selections from the Bahá'í Writings on the Reality and Immortality of the Human Soul | publisher =Bahá'í Publishing Trust | date =January 1985 | url =https://www.amazon.com/Unto-Him-Shall-Return-Immortality/dp/0877432015 | isbn =978-0877432012 }} * {{cite book | editor-last =Motlagh | editor-first =Hushidar | title =The Glorious Journey to God | publisher =Global Perspective | edition =paperback | date =May 19, 1994 | url =https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0937661023 | isbn =978-0937661024 }} * {{cite book | editor-last =Hayes | editor-first =Terril G. | editor2-last =Fisher | editor2-first =Betty J. | editor3-last =Hill | editor3-first =Richard A. | editor4-last =Cassiday | editor4-first =Terry J. | title =The Journey of the Soul: Life, Death & Immortality | publisher =Bahá'í Publishing | year =2006 | origyear =1994 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=_qG80cDNMB0C | isbn =978-1-931847-28-5 }} == Near-death experiences == ===Literature=== In addition to outlining scriptural references examining the afterlife some have specifically examined parallels between the statements in the scriptures and scholarly statements about stages of [[Near-death experience]]s, notably: * ''Light After Death''{{cite book | last =Bryson | first = Alan | title =Light After Death | publisher =Sterling Publishers Pvt. Ltd | edition =2nd | year = 2004 | origyear =1993 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=WSEsWN-6BUEC | isbn = 9781904910015}} originally published in 1993 and reprinted in 1997 and 2003{{cite web| title =Book Reviews & Thesis Papers | publisher =nderf.org | url =http://www.nderf.org/NDERF/Books/Books_and_Reviews.htm | accessdate = 2013-01-19}} 2004 and 2006 and is also offered free online{{cite web| last =Bryson | first = Alan | title =Life After Death - an exploration of the near-death-experience and the Bahá'í Faith (Free online edition) | url =http://home.arcor.de/unity9/LightAfterDeath.html | accessdate = 2013-01-19}} where he notes{{cite web | last =Bryson | first = Alan | title = Why publish on the Web for free? | url =http://home.arcor.de/unity9/note.htm | accessdate = 2013-01-19}}"…this book was never about money or profit." and "Proceeds from this book have been donated to the Rabbani School" (a [[Bahá'í school]] in India.) Across 112 pages he outlines chapters on realm of light, being of light, reunion, universal knowledge, ineffability, the soul, immortality, the transformation of values that results and compares these with scriptural references of the religion. * ''The Purpose of Physical Reality''{{cite book | last = Hatcher | first =John S. | title =The Purpose of Physical Reality| chapter =The Eternal Consequences of our Physical Performance: Hell, Heaven, or "None of the Above" | chapterurl =https://books.google.com/books?id=vnTPWaMN_RMC&pg=PA187|publisher =Bahá'í Publishing Trust | year = 2005 | origyear =1987 | pages = - 187–218 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=vnTPWaMN_RMC |isbn = 9781931847230}} published in 1987 and revised in 2005 has a chapter to this purpose: "The Eternal Consequences of our Physical Performance: Hell, Heaven or "None of the Above". Across 31 pages in his chapter he outlines sections on fear of death, passage to the next world, the effects of NDE on contemporary attitudes about the afterlife, dissociation of soul and body, awareness of other souls, the ineffable nature of the experience, the purpose of life, negative experiences in the afterlife, accountability, a loving and forgiving God, self-judgment, and bewildered ones again discussing and comparing each subject with Bahá'í scriptural references. * ''The Handbook of Near-Death Experiences: Thirty Years of Investigation'' has a chapter, "World Religions and Near-Death Experiences" by Farnaz Masumian, which reviews across religions. About 4 and a half pages are spent on the Bahá'í Faith's comparisons. Many qualities reported by NDErs find parallels in Bahá'í writings{{cite book| last =Masumian| first = Farnaz | title =Life After Death: A Study of the Afterlife in World Religions | chapter =The Bahá'í Faith | chapterurl =https://books.google.com/books?id=dI1WEwE2W90C&lpg=PP1&pg=PA89#v=onepage | publisher =Kalimat Press | edition = illustrated, reprint | year = 2002 | pages =87–111 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=dI1WEwE2W90C | isbn = 9781890688271 }}{{cite book | last = Hatcher | first =John S. | title =The Purpose of Physical Reality| chapter =The Eternal Consequences of our Physical Performance: Hell, Heaven, or "None of the Above" | chapterurl =https://books.google.com/books?id=vnTPWaMN_RMC&pg=PA187|publisher =Bahá'í Publishing Trust |year = 2005 | origyear =1987 | pages = - 187–218 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=vnTPWaMN_RMC |isbn = 9781931847230}} - the quality of the experience being ineffable, having a heavenly body, a realm of light, meeting others, reviewing one's life, and meeting a superlative being of light. Additionally the kinds of positive transformation the NDErs report also find parallels in the values Bahá'ís are encouraged to seek - a new appreciation of knowledge and learning, the importance of love, an absence of fear of death, the importance of physical life on earth, a belief in the sanctity of human nature, and an emphasis on manifesting such positive attributes as love, justice, selfless service, unity, and peace - something viewed by NDErs and Bahá'ís as being important to all religions and rising above specifics of doctrines and sectarianism. Negative experiences of NDErs are also paralleled in Bahá'í writings - the effect of suicide, the prospect of "limbo" for "breaking the rules", that when taking the chance to learn from mistakes is important and that the life review includes facing the negative deeds done, even of hellish experiences. In a paper describing patterns of understanding spiritual dreams and visions by Necati Alkan, [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], a key authority in the Bahá'í Faith, sometimes separates dreams and visions into three categories: true, interpretative, and confused.{{cite journal | last =Alkan | first = Necati | title =Dreams and their Interpretation in the Baha’i Religion Some preliminary remarks | journal =Online Journal of Bahá‟í Studies | volume =1 | issue = | pages =171–179 | publisher = | location = | year =2007 | language = | url = http://oj.bahaistudies.net/OJBS_1_Alkan_Dreams_Introductory.pdf | jstor = | issn =1177-8547 | accessdate = November 16, 2014}} The first do not need interpretation but depend on having, according to `Abdu'l-Bahá in the words of Necati Alkan, "a heart rid of all attachment and there must not exist idle thoughts in the mind." The second can be decoded for the truth, and the third only reflect "the strife and contention" of the experiencer. According to `Abdu'l-Bahá, the work of decoding the second type is like, in Necati Alkan words, "if you add any colour to a white cloth, it will accept it; but if you add blue to a yellow cloth, it will become green and the truth is distorted. In order to have the true colour, one needs to remove the added colour." Indeed, sometimes `Abdu'l-Bahá notes such experiences can mean the opposite of what they seem.{{cite book | last =‘Abdu’l-Bahá | authorlink =‘Abdu’l-Bahá | title =Tablets of Abdul-Baha Abbas | publisher =Bahá’í Publishing Committee | year =1909 | page =427 | url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TAB/tab-470.html.utf8#gr3}} === Personal presentations === In addition to general reviews of the statements of scriptures and comparisons of them with near death experiences in general there are a few individuals who have had their experiences published and shared. ==== Reinee Pasarow ==== Reinee Pasarow has presented her experiences which she relates to the religion. She published her story as early as 1981.{{cite journal | last = Pasarow | first =R. | title =A Personal Account of an NDE | journal =Vital Signs | volume =1 | issue =3 | pages =11–14 | year =1981 }} At least one extended talk was video taped and is available online in a couple places.*{{cite web | last =Pasarow | first = Reinee |title =Is there life after death? New death experience of Renee Pasarow, Part 1 | publisher =Local Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Moorpark, Ca. | year =1991 | url =http://bahaivideo.com/media/renee1.swf | format = Shockwave movie | accessdate = 2013-01-19}} * {{cite web | last =Pasarow | first = Reinee | title =Is there life after death? New death experience of Renee Pasarow, Part 2 | publisher =Local Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Moorpark, Ca. | year =1991 | url =http://bahaivideo.com/media/renee2.swf | format =Shockwave movie | accessdate = 2013-01-19}} * {{cite web | last =Pasarow | first = Reinee | title = Near Death Experience of Renee Pasarow | publisher =Local Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Moorpark, Ca. | year =1991 | url =http://lightafterlife.com | format = video | accessdate = 2013-01-19}} There are also extended partial transcripts.{{cite web | title =Reinee Pasarow | work =Near-Death Experiences & the Afterlife | publisher =near-death.com | year =2011 | url =http://www.near-death.com/forum/nde/000/64.html | accessdate =2013-01-19 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130201192711/http://near-death.com/forum/nde/000/64.html | archive-date =2013-02-01 | dead-url =yes | df = }}{{cite book| last = Almeder | first =Robert F. | title =Death and Personal Survival: The Evidence for Life After Death | publisher =Rowman & Littlefield | year =1992 | pages =170–? | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=K8-_Vqq6r-cC&lpg=PR9 | isbn = 9780822630166 }} The talk has been analyzed from a religious point of view in a commentary{{cite web | title =A Glimpse of Paradise - A Video or DVD on the Afterlife; Some Comments from Dr. Motlagh about Mrs. Pasarow’s Dreams and Near Death Visions that Guided Her to Bahá’u’lláh | publisher =www.globalperspective.org | url =http://www.globalperspective.org/video.html | accessdate =2013-01-19 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20140424202309/https://www.globalperspective.org/video.html | archive-date =2014-04-24 | dead-url =yes | df = }} and beyond.{{cite web | title =The Exploration of Life After Death | publisher =soc.hawaii.edu | date =May 3, 1993 | url =http://www.soc.hawaii.edu/leonj/updates/baracao/paper19.htm | accessdate = 2013-01-19}} There is also an audio file of a similar but not identical talk.{{cite web | title =Near-Death Vision, a talk by Reinee Pasarow | work =Audio files | publisher =bahaitext.info | url =http://bahaitext.info/xyaudiodown.htm | accessdate = 2013-01-19}} She felt her relationship with the religion came as a direct result of her NDE. ==== Ricky Bradshaw ==== [[P. M. H. Atwater]] claims Ricky Bradshaw co-founded [[International Association for Near-Death Studies]] (IANDS) with Dr. [[Kenneth Ring]].{{cite book | last =Atwater | first = P. M. H. | authorlink =P. M. H. Atwater | title =Coming Back to Life | publisher =Citadel Press |edition =Revised and Updated | date =October 2001 | pages =58, 111–112 | url = }} He also joined the Bahá'í Faith as it was the best fit to his experiences in his view. His experience was reviewed in a number of publications*{{cite book | last =Atwater | first = P. M. H. |authorlink =P. M. H. Atwater | title =Coming Back to Life | publisher =Citadel Press | edition =Revised and Updated | date =October 2001 | pages =58, 111–112| url = }} * {{cite web | last =Beer | first = Heidrun | title =Review of P.M.H. Atwater: The Big Book of Near-Death Experiences | work =Book Reviews |publisher =Arbitskreis für mentales Training, Startseite | date =November 24, 2008 | url =http://www.sgmt.at/BookReviews/Review4.htm | accessdate =2013-01-19}} * {{cite book | last =Turner | first = Edith | title =Religion and Healing in America | editor-last = Barnes | editor-first =Linda L. | editor2-last = Sered | editor2-first =Susan S. | contribution =Taking Seriously the nature of Religious Healing | contribution-url =https://books.google.com/books?id=Uo5iIkzuSfEC&pg=PA399| publisher =Oxford University Press | edition =paperback | year =2004 | pages =399–400 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=Uo5iIkzuSfEC | isbn = 9780195167962}} and there are references to Bradshaw publishing his experience in some early journals not onlinecitation 112 in {{cite book | last =Zaleski | first = Carol | title =Otherworld Journeys: Accounts of Near-Death Experience in Medieval and Modern Times | publisher =Oxford University Press | edition =reprint | year =1988 | pages = 237 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=_6tVwVF6w10C&pg=PA237 | isbn = 9780195056655 }} indicating it was published in an early version of an NDE journal named (at the time) ''Anabiosis: Journal of Near Death Studies'', August 1979, page 11. ==== Others mentioned in relation to the religion ==== In addition to the above, two others have reported NDEs and have some relationship to the religion. In Atwater's more recent book ''Near-Death Experiences, the Rest of the Story: What They Teach Us about Living and Dying and Our True Purpose''{{cite book| last = Atwater | first =P. M. H. | title =Near-Death Experiences, the Rest of the Story: What They Teach Us about Living and Dying and Our True Purpose | publisher =Hampton Roads Publishing| year = 2011 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=zyAttorNyXMC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA257 | isbn = 9781571746511}} on p. 257 Atwater records an anecdote of another reference to the religion:
"It is my opinion," said Teri, "that Michael has been living with the aftereffects since childhood. One afternoon he called me and asked if I wanted to go to church with him. I said no, but I would love to take him to [[Bahá'í House of Worship (Wilmette, Illinois)| Bahá'í Temple in Wilmette]]. After climbing the stairs to the Temple together we walked in a circle, reading inscriptions over the doors. Over one set of doors, facing East, we paused to read, "Ye are the fruits of one tree and the leaves of one branch.' I looked up at Michael as tears welled in his eyes. I could feel his pain and frustration. It was the kind of frustration that comes with the knowledge of having crossed over, of having been 'there', of having returned from the threshold of death carrying his message for mankind with a remote memory of 'the other side'."
Nina Lembcke Holte Harvey has been interviewed by Warren Odess-Gillett on "A Bahá'í Perspective" for [[WXOJ-LP]] about her NDEs in her childhood.{{cite episode| title =Nina Lembcke Holte Harvey| episodelink =| url =http://www.bahaipodcast.com/assets/mp3/abp-246.mp3| series =A Bahá'í Perspective| credits =Warren Odess-Gillett| station =WXOJ-LP|location=Northampton MA| airdate =October 29, 2011| season =7|number =27}} Chief Albert Isaac of [[Aishihik]] is recorded as having identified a near death experience of his in 1957 with the Bahá'í Faith.{{cite journal| last =Echevarria| first = Lynn | title =A new skin for an old drum: changing contexts of Yukon Aboriginal Bahá'í storytelling| journal =Northern Review| volume =29 | issue =Fall 2008| pages = 39–55 | year =2008 | url =http://bahai-library.com/echevarria_aboriginal_bahai_storytelling |accessdate = 2013-01-11}} Marie Watson, author of ''Two Paths'' in 1897,{{cite book|author=Marie Watson|title=The Two Paths|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mqs3AAAAYAAJ|year=1897|publisher=A.C. Clark}} says she suffered a car accident in 1890 in Washington DC and reported having a vision and met a guide.{{cite book | last =Watson | first =Marie | authorlink = | title =My Pilgrimage to the Land of Desire | publisher =Executor of the estate of Marie Watson and the Bahá'í Publishing Committee of New York | year =1932 | pages =13–14 | url =}} She converted to the religion in 1901 and identified the guide as `Abdu'l-Bahá. == See also == * [[Bahá'í cosmology]] * [[Bahá'í teachings]] * [[Bahá'í views on sin]] * [[Guy Murchie#The Seven Mysteries of Life|Guy Murchie's ''The Seven Mysteries of Life'']] * [[Rūḥ]], the soul in Islam and Sufism == Further reading == * {{cite book | last =Bryson | first = Alan | title =Light After Death | publisher =Sterling Publishers Pvt. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Use British English|date=September 2018}}
'''Bedgebury Forest Woman''' refers to an unknown female decedent who was found in [[Bedgebury Forest]], [[Kent]], [[England]] on 23 October 1979. Despite multiple investigations, an arrest and a trial the woman has never been identified.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/7056796.stm|title=New appeal over 1979 forest death|last=|first=|date=2007-10-22|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Discovery of the victim == The body was found by a woman riding on horseback through [[Bedgebury Forest]] on Tuesday, 23 October 1979.<ref name=":5">{{Cite episode|series=[[Crimewatch]]|station=BBC One|date=December 1984|time=23m40s}}</ref> The forest floor was dry as the weather had been dry and sunny for a few weeks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.london-weather.eu/article.118.html|title=London Weather - 1979 Cool. Cold Winter, Wet Spring and Dry Summer|website=www.london-weather.eu|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref> The body had been battered, mutilated, murdered and dumped but little attempt had been made to conceal the body and it was apparent in the undergrowth from the riders position.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/new-test-reopens-unsolved-murders-1071002.html|title=New test reopens unsolved murders|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-10-14|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name=":5" /> The victim had suffered massive head injuries from a beating.<ref name=":1" /> A bloodstained wooden stake found near the victims body was later concluded to have been the murder weapon.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/737838.stm|title=BBC News {{!}} UK {{!}} Pensioner faces hitcher killer trial|website=news.bbc.co.uk|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref> No handbag or means of identification were found with the body.<ref name=":5" /> Police believe that the victim had been killed up to five days prior to her discovery.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/778172.stm|title=BBC News {{!}} UK {{!}} Driver not guilty of hitcher murder|website=news.bbc.co.uk|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref>
== Description of the victim == The severity of the injuries to the woman’s head and body prevented identification.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/may/06/2|title=Man, 75, in court over 1979 killing|last=Mcleod|first=Maurice|date=2000-05-06|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref> The woman was aged between 30 and 35, she was quite short at 5ft 1in and she had a thin build.<ref name=":0" /> She had brown eyes and straight shoulder-length hair which she had kept in its natural, dark-brown colour<ref name=":0" />
The victim was wearing black shoes, a distinctive floral dress, a black polo neck jumper<ref name=":0" /> and a yellow blouse<ref name=":8" />. The police stated that the black and white patterned dress was the clue that was most likely to lead to the discovery of her identity.<ref name=":5" /> The dress was found to have been homemade from furniture fabric.<ref name=":7" /> It had been altered on multiple occasions; once to the [[hem]] and another to the chest area.<ref name=":7">{{Cite episode|series=[[Crimewatch]]|station=BBC One|date=December 1994|time=27m00s}}</ref> The dress had been purchased at a [[Charity shop|charity]], or [[Second-hand shop|second hand]] shop.<ref name=":7" /> Police believed that the victim was very poor<ref name=":7" /> and possibly from the [[Northern England|north]] of England.<ref name=":2" />
The autopsy revealed that the victim had an [[ectopic pregnancy]] which had been present for 4-6 weeks and bleeding for 2-3 weeks.<ref name=":6">{{Cite episode|series=[[Crimewatch]]|station=BBC One|date=December 1984|time=24m40s}}</ref> The victim would have been in severe pain and may have visited a doctor suspecting [[appendicitis]] as the pain would have occurred on her right side.<ref name=":6" /> [[Stretch marks]] on her stomach indicated that she had probably given birth to at least one child.<ref name=":6" />
The victim’s [[molars]] were very worn down and she had [[Wisdom tooth|wisdom teeth]] which indicated that she was at least 30 years old.<ref name=":6" /> There was no evidence that the victim had ever visited a [[dentist]] in her life.<ref name=":6" /> The victim had prominent, visibly decayed teeth.<ref name=":9">{{Cite episode|series=[[Crimewatch]]|station=BBC One|date=February 1999|time=22m10s}}</ref> No [[nicotine]] staining was found on the victim’s hands, teeth or lungs.<ref name=":6" /> Additionally, the victim’s lungs did not exhibit the carbon deposits typical of a city-dweller, indicating that she probably lived in the countryside.<ref name=":6" /> Police believe the woman was of no fixed address and was a regular [[hitchhiker]] along the [[M1 motorway|M1]] and [[M6 motorway|M6]] motorways and may have had a connection with the [[Vale of Evesham]].<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9" /> There was a possibility that she may have been working as a [[prostitute|sex worker]], operating from [[Spitalfields]] in [[London]].<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases-int/462ufuk.html|title=The Doe Network: 462UFUK|website=www.doenetwork.org|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref> == Initial investigation == After the discovery the police searched the missing persons databases at [[New Scotland Yard]] and the UK [[Social services|Social Services]].<ref name=":5" /> Hospitals and doctors surgeries were also polled for persons who matched the description of the woman.<ref name=":5" /> A large poster campaign was launched throughout the UK and Europe.<ref name=":5" /> All of these investigative efforts failed to produce a match to the woman's identity.<ref name=":5" />
== Subsequent events ==
=== Crimewatch 1984 === In December 1984 the victim was featured on an episode of the [[BBC]] TV program, [[Crimewatch]]. Police appealed for the persons that made, or altered the black and white dress to come forward.<ref name=":7" />
=== Reopening of the case === In October 1998 the case was reopened after an investigation by [[forensic scientists]] on archived evidence.<ref name=":1" /> The victim's case was highlighted in the national media as one of a number of such cases that had been reopened due to a new DNA technique that enabled the generation of DNA profiles from much smaller samples than had been previously possible.<ref name=":1" /> The size of these samples was described as being as small as a single blood cell, or a flake of skin.<ref name=":1" />
=== Arrest === In January 1999 the first arrest in the case was made.<ref name=":1" /> Harry J R Pennells (b. q1 1925)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?r=152477583:3115&d=bmd_1537384567|title=Harry J R Pennells|last=|first=|date=|website=Free BMD|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, then 75, of [[Ticehurst]], [[East Sussex]] was charged with the victim’s murder.<ref name=":0" /> Pennells, who was 54 at the time of the murder<ref name=":3" /> was a retired lorry driver<ref name=":0" /> and had worked for Henley’s Transport who were based in [[Kent]] at the time of the murder.<ref name=":4" /> Pennells had originally been questioned by police a few days after the discovery of the body.<ref name=":2" /> He had been interviewed three times between 1979 and 1980<ref name=":3" /> and was one of a number of suspects.<ref name=":4" /> He had not been charged following the initial investigation,<ref name=":2" /> however, after specks of blood found in his lorry in 1979 were re-examined and linked to the victim police were able to make their arrest.<ref name=":2" /> Pennells was subsequently bailed and a report was sent to the [[Crown Prosecution Service]].<ref name=":1" />
=== Crimewatch 1999 === On 22 February 1999 the victim’s case was featured on Crimewatch for a second time.<ref name=":9" /> It was revealed that after the original Crimewatch appeal in 1984 the person who made the black-and-white dress had made contact. The woman, who was from [[Stratford-upon-Avon]] stated that she had given the dress to a charity shop in [[Evesham]], [[Worcestershire]] after which, police could not trace it.<ref name=":9" /> It appeared to have been subsequently altered to shorten the length, remove the zip from the back and add a black lace ruff to the collar. An appeal was made for the person who made these alterations to come forward.<ref name=":9" />
=== Trial === The trial started on 4 May 2000 at [[Maidstone]] [[Crown Court]].<ref name=":2" /> Pennells was accused of picking up the victim at [[Spitalfields Market Constabulary|Spitalfields Market]] on 19 October 1979,<ref name=":3" /> taking her in his lorry to a delivery in [[Keighley]], [[West Yorkshire]], then back to drop her off in South London on the morning of the 20th October<ref name=":3" /> and beating the victim to death with a wooden stake.<ref name=":3" /> Pennells told the court that he had picked up a female hitchhiker.<ref name=":2" /> He admitted that the hitchhiker may have been the victim, but that he had dropped her off alive and was innocent of her murder.<ref name=":3" />
Witnesses called by the prosecution stated that they had seen a woman matching the victims description in Bedgebury Forest on 21 October 1979 which was the day after the murder was suspected to have happened according to some estimates.<ref name=":3" /> Two witnesses who were at the [[Keighley|Keighley]] lorry depot stated that they saw, and spoke to, a young woman who was with Pennells.<ref name=":4" /> Staff at the Henley Transport's [[Rochdale]] depot also stated that they saw Pennells with a woman who was similar to an artist's impression made of the victim.<ref name=":4" />
Samples of blood and flakes of hair found in a sleeping bag on the passenger seat of the lorry matched the DNA profile of the victim.<ref name=":2" /> Additionally, particles of foam from a mattress in the cab of the lorry were found on the victim's dress.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" />
The trial lasted for four weeks, after which Pennells was found not guilty<ref name=":0" /> in an unanimous decision made after the jury deliberated for 1 hour and 15 minutes.<ref name=":3" />
=== Subsequent appeals to identify the victim === In October 2007 the charity missing persons appealed to the public for someone to come forward and identify the woman.<ref name=":0" />

{{eastern name order|Blaskó Béla Ferenc Dezső}} {{more citations needed|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Bela Lugosi | image = Bela Lugosi as Dracula, anonymous photograph from 1931, Universal Studios.jpg | image_size = | caption = Bela Lugosi as ''Dracula'' (1931) | birth_name = Béla Ferenc Dezső Blaskó | birth_date = {{birth date|1882|10|20|df=yes}} | birth_place = Lugos, [[Austria-Hungary]] (now [[Lugoj]], Romania) | death_date = {{death date and age|1956|08|16|1882|10|20|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles]], California, U.S. | resting place = [[Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver City|Holy Cross Cemetery]] | occupation = Actor | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 1 | years_active = 1901/02–1956 | other_names = "The King of Horror" | website = {{url|http://belalugosi.com}} | spouse = {{marriage|Ilona Szmick|1917|1920|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Ilona von Montagh|1921|1924|end=divorced}}
